title: Modeling Behavior
text:
Sample Description



The full sample contains 1760 participants (Mean age = 20.8, SD = 2.1, range: [16.8, 30.83]; Sex: 58.9% females, 41.1% males, 0.0% other).

title: Modeling Behavior
text:
Distribution

Figure 1: Distributions for All Tasks. They are all all fairly distributed as normal.

title: Modeling Behavior
text:
Correlation Matrix

Figure 3: Correlation Between Tasks

title: Modeling Behavior
text:
Simple One-g CFA

Figure 4: Factor loadings for one factor only. Note the largest loadings are mainly from response time tasks. The fit measures are also low.

title: Modeling Behavior
text:
Enhance Model Fitting
Given the previous model does not fit well, item deletion and model re-factor (hierarchical model) are tried. The deleted items are:

All the inhibition tasks (anti-saccade, stop signal, stroop), because they do not fit well as an inhibition factor.
Penn line orientation task is related to perception, which does not have enough similar tasks.
Spatial 2-back task, because its correlation with other WM tasks is relatively low and its loading on WM factor is low.

title: Modeling Behavior
text:

Figure 5: Visualization of the new model.

title: Predict Intelligence by FC Network through CPM
text:
Configurations
Parameters are as follows (mainly inspired by Greene et al. (2018)):

FMRI data pre-processing: with or without global signal regression (GSR)
Node parcellation: Power’s 264 nodes (Power264) or Shen’s 268 nodes (nn268)
Modality:

emotion
facename
nback, Nbackrun1 and Nbackrun2: the n-back task contains two runs, and nback denotes that these two runs are combined.
4tasks: combines emotion, facename, Nbackrun1 and Nbackrun2
rest
4tasksrest: combines all tasks and rest modality data

Edge selection threshold method: correlation p.value based (alpha) or network sparsity based (sparsity)

title: Predict Intelligence by FC Network through CPM
text:
Different Modality

Figure 1: CPM prediction among different modality. These results show task modality does have a better prediction than resting (rest2) modality. rest2 means using subjects also having task data, while rest means using all subjects as long as they have resting data. Interestingly, negative edges (anti-correlation) predict better than postive edges for resting data (rest2).
